intro: Acalypha persimilis var. scabra, commonly known as roughleaf ironweed, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its rough, hairy leaves and clusters of small, yellowish-green flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, open habitats such as wetlands and disturbed areas. Its botanical features include opposite leaf arrangement and showy bracts that accompany the flower clusters. It is valued for its ornamental appeal and ecological benefits in supporting pollinators.

This plant thrives in humid, shaded environments within lowland and hill forests. It is commonly found in areas with rich, moist soil and high levels of biodiversity. The species is often associated with secondary growth and disturbed habitats. Its distribution is limited to specific ecological niches within its native range.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acalypha persimilis var. scabra was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as an ornamental plant due to its attractive foliage. The plant has since become naturalized in certain regions of the country. It is commonly found in coastal and disturbed habitats.
